However, it was very clear that there was no going back; they were not willing to go back on the decision they had made because the board of the parent company had made that decision and had made it clear all along that the only basis on which they would support the management buyout was with a decisive vote from the workers.

Today the workers were told of the management decision and, although the Chairman of the Labour Court made it clear that she was willing to intervene, the company is not prepared to facilitate a hearing tomorrow before the Labour Court. We may regret that. I certainly regret it. The SIPTU official, Ms Jeanette Hughes, said today that the decision was final, that there was no way of going back.

However, we must not engage in the blame game. We must look to the future, and it is with that in mind that this morning I invited the County Manager, Mr. Des Mahon, to chair the new North Mayo Enterprise Initiative. It will include members of the IDA, Forbairt, FÁS and from the Ballina Chamber of Commerce, a representative from the local community and Bishop Finnegan. I hope they will set about their task very quickly. I intend to meet them shortly, and the Government will give them every support in seeking alternative opportunities for the workers involved here and for the region generally. We hope that our combined efforts, the partnership approach that we are supporting in making this announcement, will succeed in delivering an alternative opportunity for the workers and their families in a region that will tonight be very devastated by what they have just heard. I hope that this initiative will work in the same way as the initiatives taken when there were factory closures in Tallaght, Ballyfermot, Tipperary and Galway. People working together, focused on the future, wanting to provide opportunities and fill the vacuum that will inevitably be created can achieve an enormous amount. In that, they will have my full support and that of the Government.

I thank Deputy Cooper-Flynn who has been in touch with me constantly in relation to this matter, as has the Minister of State, Deputy Moffatt. I hope to work with her and the other representatives from the area to turn around a devastating blow in a very short time.

MainHeading.Title: Adjournment Debate. - Assessment of Means.

Speaker.P: I thank the Chair for affording me the opportunity of raising this matter on the Adjournment. I congratulate the Minister on his appointment to the Department of Social Welfare of which I have some knowledge. I wish him every success.

The matter I raise relates to a reply to a parliamentary question tabled yesterday. The information in the reply was needed for a specific purpose today. A more serious problem may have been created because the information is out of date. The reply states that the assessment is based on self-employment and that this is based on the most recent figures available to the Department. On closer examination it was found that one of the most recent assessments was in 1993. Two Governments have come and gone since then.

MainHeading.P: The information should be updated for three reasons. First, a long time has elapsed; second, legislation relating to seasonal and part-time workers has changed in the meantime which would make it more beneficial to the person concerned; and, even more important, the whole source of the part-time employment which was in existence at that time has gone. That is the vital element which needed to be updated and brought to the attention of the Department. The assessment does not reflect that position. I am not attributing blame to the Minister. It is the fault of the system. It is important that up to date information is available at all times. I merely ask the Minister to examine the case in question. Up to date information would eliminate much of the confusion for the individual concerned.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: I thank the Deputy for raising this issue which was the subject of a parliamentary question tabled by him yesterday. The person concerned is in receipt of unemployment assistance at a reduced single rate on the basis of a means assessment of £33 per week. The means are derived from self-employment and are based on the most recent figures furnished to the Department by the person concerned. The means are assessed for a 12 month period up to 3 October 1995, not 1993. I accept the Deputy's comments and ask him to supply any information that would assist the Department in dealing with this matter.

The man in question was interviewed on a number of occasions about his earnings from self-employment. The inspector dealing with the case is satisfied the assessment is reasonable having regard to the man's circumstances, but is not satisfied the person concerned has ceased self-employment. The most recent decision on this case was given on 12 May 1997 by a deciding officer in my Department. The person concerned did not appeal this decision nor has he claimed supplementary welfare allowance from the community welfare officer, to which he would be entitled based on the amount of money he is receiving.

If the circumstances of the person concerned have changed it is open to him to seek a further review of his means and a form for this purpose can be obtained at his nearest local office. In the meantime payment of unemployment assistance will continue to issue at the reduced rate. Deputy Durkan should encourage this man to seek a review of his means and the Department will examine all the circumstances.
The Dáil adjourned at 4.55 p.m. until 2.30 p.m. on Tuesday, 30 September 1997.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Flags of Convenience Vessels.

Qst.Quest: the steps, if any, he intends to take to implement the commitment given in An Action Programme for the Millennium to seek the banning of flags of convenience fishing vessels from Irish waters; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the way in which he proposes to seek the banning of flags of convenience fishing vessels from Irish waters; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 11 and 17 together.

In my earlier reply to the priority question on this matter, I spelled out in detail the threefold strategy I will be pursuing to address the flagship problem. The first component of that strategy is to mount, through rigorous enforcement, an effective ban on the illegal activities of all fishing vessels, irrespective of nationality, in our waters. The second is to press, with the support of the Commission, other member states concerned to play their part in properly controlling and monitoring the activities and landings of flagships. The third is to work with the Commission and likeminded member states in order to ensure the necessary link between the economic benefits of national fish quotas and the coastal communities concerned. I am committed to making tangible progress on this threefold strategy which, I believe, is the key to delivering workable solutions on flagships and their fishing activities.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Departmental Staff.

Qst.Quest: if additional staff will be allocated to his Department in order to carry out the extra responsibilities allocated to him by the Taoiseach on the appointment of the Government.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I will ensure that the additional responsibilities assigned to the Department of the Marine and Natural Resources will be accompanied by appropriate staffing and other resources from the Departments heretofore responsible for them. The details are being worked out at present by officials from my Department, the Department of Finance, the Department of Agriculture, Food and Forstry and the Department of Transport, Energy and Communications.

MainHeading.P: It is my firm intention that sufficient high quality resources will be made available to the Department to allow it to discharge its new functions and role in maximising employment and contribution to economic development in the important areas under the aegis of my Department.

Qst.hpid: Mr. J. O'Keeffe Mr. J. O'Keeffe
Qst.Quest: the measures, if any, he proposes to take to modernise and upgrade our white fish fleet.
if he will be providing additional funding in 1997 for the modernisation of the white fish fleet; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 13 and 16 together.

A key priority in the Government's Action Programme for the Millennium, is to seek to upgrade our fishing fleet and to make the industry attractive to providers of capital by examining the provision of tax breaks and subsidised loans. As I have already confirmed to the industry, my priority is to make immediate progress on the renewal of the white fish fleet for safety and economic reasons, in line with available fishing opportunities.

I have decided, therefore, as a first step to press ahead with the introduction of a pilot grant scheme to support investment in a number of new white fish boats in order to test the viability of such vessels. I have instructed the Department and BIM to speed up the work of drawing up the necessary guidelines and conditions with a view to early clearance by the EU Commission and its implementation as quickly as possible.
I am also pursuing the necessary additional EU and Exchequer funding for the scheme.

In addition to testing the waters with the pilot grant scheme, I have also asked the Department to examine urgently the scope for tax breaks and other financial incentives to make investment in our fishing fleet more attractive to providers of capital. This will be done in full consultation with the industry itself with a view to bringing forward proposals within a very short timeframe for consideration in the context of the budget for 1998.

In addition, under the Operational Programme for Fisheries we will continue to provide funding for the modernisation of existing boats within the fishing fleet. I intend to ensure that this funding continues to support essential investment aimed at delivering on the objectives of improving the quality, efficiency and safety of the fleet as a whole. There has been good take-up to date with a significant number of applications in the system at present. I expect to be in a position to announce a new round of modernisation grants in the early autumn.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the urgent necessity of dredging Burtonport Harbour, County Donegal; the current position regarding the proposed dredging; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I am aware of the need for additional dredging works at Burtonport Harbour. Funding has been provided in the 1997 fishery harbour development programme towards the cost of the necessary technical investigations which are a prerequisite of such a scheme. A dredging programme will be considered in the light of the findings of the site investigations. The Department is currently in discussion with Donegal County Council on the practical arrangements for undertaking the technical investigations. I am advised that the county council will take a decision shortly on whether it is in a position to undertake these works directly with, of course, whatever practical assistance the Department's engineers can provide.

Qst.Quest: when the lease of Comhar Iascairí Éireann Teoranta at West Pier, Howth, County Dublin will be renewed in view of the impressive record and plans of this co-operative.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: I fully agree with the Deputy on the importance of ensuring a viable future for the fishermen based in Howth. On all the advice available to me, however, I am not convinced that the co-operative in question, as presently constituted, is the appropriate vehicle for progressing the interests of the fishermen concerned. It is also the case that, given the unsatisfactory history of the cooperative's tenancy at Howth over the years, I am not in a position to renew the lease to which the Deputy refers.

In order to take matters forward, however, I have requested the Department, in consultation with the Howth fishermen, to review all possible options for encouraging the take-up of genuine fishing opportunities, together with scope for a soundly-based strategy to facilitate marketing, distribution and value-added.

Qst.Dept: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise and Employment
Qst.askee: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise and Employment
Qst.Quest: the number of people on community employment schemes in each of the years 1995 and 1996; whether the Government has reduced the numbers allowed onto schemes and, if not, the plans, if any, there are to reduce the number of these places.

Speaker.hpid: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Miss Harney) Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Miss Harney)
Speaker.NameTxt: Tánaiste and Minister for Enterprise and Employment (Miss Harney)
Speaker.P: The average participation level on community employment — CE — through 1995 was 40,052 and 39,550 through 1996. The average participation level set for 1997 is 40,000 and I have no plans to change this level.

Qst.Quest: if it is proposed to submit the proposal for the development of a deep sea port at Ross, Killala, County Mayo, to the EU for funding; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for the Marine (Dr. Woods) Michael J. Woods
Speaker.P: In November 1994 my Department contributed £5,000 towards the cost of carrying out an economic and feasibility study, undertaken by a firm of consultants, McCarthy and Partners, for a proposed deep water berthing facilities at Ross Point, Killala, County Mayo. This study was a follow on to earlier studies carried out in 1978 and again in 1983 by McCarthy and Partners. The development proposals at Ross Point involves an investment of between £6 million and £10 million. The final report received in February 1996 indicated that it would be unrealistic to proceed with the construction of a jetty before a commitment has been received from a suitable and substantial new “anchor” industry. As of now there is no market demand for deep water facilities at Killala.

Qst.Quest: if he will make financial assistance available to enable Charlestown Theatre Group to avail of the invitation to perform the play, The Aristocrats, in Israel on 4 November 1997; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. R. Burke) Raphael P. Burke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr. R. Burke)
Speaker.P: The application from the company named by the Deputy will be fully considered at the next meeting, scheduled for 8 September 1997, of the Cultural Relations Committee, the body which makes recommendations on funding for cultural events abroad through my Department. The applicant will be informed of the outcome as soon as a decision is made.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: the number of companies carrying out offshore exploration in 1997; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: To date four groups holding offshore petroleum authorisations are drilling or plan to undertake drilling programmes in the Irish offshore during 1997. Total Oil Marine plc commenced drilling an exploration well on 3 July 1997 in block 35/17 in the Porcupine Basin off the south-west coast of Ireland. Marathon plan to drill an exploration well in block 35/30 this year, also in the Porcupine Basin. Current expectations are that the well will commence in late July or early August. Both of those wells will be drilled under Frontier Exploration Licences granted in 1995.

Enterprise Oil plc proposes to drill an exploration well in the Kish Bank Basin, offshore Dublin, and while it has not yet set a definite date for drilling they expect to be in a position to commence towards the end of the year. Statoil, which holds a Lease Undertaking over the Connemara Field in block 26/28, also in the Porcupine Basin, is currently conducting a two well appraisal programme on the field to determine whether it can be brought into long-term commercial production. An essential part of this appraisal work is to produce oil as part of a long-term test from the field over a period of about two months and is expected to begin today.

Four companies have acquired a total of almost 15,000 kilometres of 2D seismic data in the South Porcupine Basin so far this year. Another company is in the process of conducting a 420 square kilometre-3D seismic survey in the Slyne Trough. In addition five companies have plans to conduct further seismic surveys off the west coast of Ireland and in the Celtic Sea within the next few months.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Superannuation Schemes.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: if she will give details of the co-ordination introduced on instructions from her Department in 1970 into the pension scheme of many Aer Lingus and Aer Rianta staff whereby, for those staff who joined after 1 April 1970, the current social welfare old age pension rate is deducted from their superannuation entitlement before payment; the reason this co-ordination was introduced; the companies or category of workers involved; if it is covered by legislation; if her attention has been drawn to concerns in this regard; if it will be removed; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: While I have a statutory role in relation to the superannuation schemes in some State bodies — under section 20 of the Air Companies Act, 1966, all changes to the existing schemes in Aer Lingus and Aer Rianta are subject to my approval, following consultation with the Minister for Finance — the determination of general policy in relation to such schemes is a matter for the Minister for Finance. Having said that, the co-ordinated arrangements which apply since 1970 are inherently logical and there is no proposal to change them. Under these arrangements, eligibility for social welfare pensions, where it arises is taken into account in setting the arrangements in vocational schemes both in relation to contributions and benefits.

MainHeading.P: In the case under reference co-ordination was introduced in the context of proposed amendments to the Irish Airlines (General Employees) Superannuation Scheme. In the course of granting approval for those changes, the then Department of Transport and Power required that the scheme be co-ordinated with social welfare benefits. This arrangement applied to new members joining the scheme after 1 April 1970. Existing members were given the option of joining the new arrangements or remaining in the existing scheme. This type of co-ordination is now a fundamental feature of most public and private sector schemes and since April 1995, has been extended to all new entrants to the public service who are on full PRSI.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: if she will give an estimated timeframe within which she hopes to have the community deflector system problem resolved; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, she has made since taking up office in relation to the community deflector systems; and if she will make a statement on the matter.

Qst.askee: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications
Qst.Quest: when she will legalise the community deflector systems as committed to by her party when in Opposition.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mrs. O'Rourke) Mary O'Rourke
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Transport, Energy and Communications (Mrs. O'Rourke)
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 25, 26 and 27 together.

The licensing of television deflector operators is a very complex issue. I am currently familiarising myself with the issue and I will be evaluating the various policy options. While I will continue to exercise a role in relation to overall policy on the allocation and use of radio frequency spectrum, the legal power to issue licences to television deflector operators pursuant to section 5 of the Wireless Telegraphy Act, 1926 was transferred, with effect from 30 June 1997, to the Director of Telecommunications Regulation under the (Miscellaneous Provisions) Act, 1996. It is, accordingly, a legal function of the director in the first instance to address the question of licensing such operators. Any licensing regulations proposed by the Director of Telecommunications Regulation would be subject to my consent.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: if he will have arrangements made to make payment in respect of an area aid application to a person (details supplied) in County Offaly.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Under the terms of the EU regulations governing area aid schemes, member states are required to take the measures necessary to avoid the situation where the conversion of existing holdings or the creation of new holdings after 30 June 1992 leads to the patently improper avoidance of the provisions relating to individual limits on eligibility for premia or setaside obligations. Therefore, any new applicants to the area aid scheme must, if requested, satisfy my Department that they are farming their declared lands entirely separately from those of any other applicant.

Following an inspection of the holding in this case, my Department is not satisfied that the individual to whom the Deputy refers is farming the lands declared in his 1996 area aid application as a separate business. In the circumstances, therefore, it is not in a position to make a payment in this case.

Qst.askee: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry
Qst.Quest: the current position in relation to the acquisition of new markets for Irish beef; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Walsh) Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Agriculture, Food and Forestry (Mr. Walsh)
Speaker.P: Ireland already exports cattle and beef to over 60 markets worldwide. Given the importance of this sector to the national economy, no effort has been spared to maintain existing markets and to secure additional outlets for Irish product.

Officials from my Department visited Libya, Russia, Egypt, Iran and the Gulf States to promote Irish beef. Already this year, agreement on veterinary certification has been secured with Egypt and the United Arab Emirates thus ensuring that beef exports will continue unimpeded to these destinations. As regards Russia, beef exports are continuing at significant levels and further discussions are envisaged with the Russian authorities in the near future in order to have the current restrictions on Irish beef reviewed. On Iran, technical discussions are continuing with a view to agreeing an acceptable veterinary Protocol.

MainHeading.P: In the countries which import Irish beef and cattle, and particularly in the Middle East, contact has been maintained with the authorities either directly or through the diplomatic service on the spot, who keep me informed in detail of developments which affect our exports and who accord the highest priority to ensuring access for Irish products to these important markets. Various delegations have also been received from a number of these countries.

In addition to the above, the Department of Foreign Affairs, An Bord Bia and my Department are actively engaged in seeking new markets in other countries such as Morocco, Syria, Poland, Azerbaijan and Turkey which do not as yet have a tradition in importing Irish beef.

Qst.Quest: the total cost incurred in relation to the recount at the RDS after the recent general election which lasted one week; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: Because details of the various components of the cost have not yet been finalised and approved, I am not in a position at this stage to be able to advise the Deputy of the total costs involved. When the information is available, I will arrange to have it conveyed to him.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Freedom of Information Act.

Qst.Quest: the arrangements, if any, which are being put in place for the implementation of the Freedom of Information Act; the Department which will be responsible for the implementation of the Act; if the deadlines for the introduction of the provisions of the Act set by the previous Government will be adhered to; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Finance (Mr. McCreevy) Charlie McCreevy
Speaker.P: The Freedom of Information Act was passed into law on 21 April 1997. The Act will commence for Government Departments and certain other public bodies on 21 April 1998, i.e. 12 months from enactment as provided for in section 1 (2) of the Act. Each individual Department and public body must ensure that the rights conferred by the Freedom of Information Act can be exercised fully and effectively by citizens, clients and customers of their services from the date of commencement.

MainHeading.P: To assist Departments and other public bodies in their preparations for meeting the requirements of the legislation, a central policy unit was established in my Department. This unit is now leading the implementation process and providing ongoing advice and support to public bodies in their general preparations for commencement of the legislation. In addition, by working with Departments through a high level interdepartmental working group, key issues are being addressed so as to ensure its effective application in areas such as: the provision of training for freedom of information; guidance in relation to key publications required under sections 15 and 16 of the Act; and improvement in systems for managing information so as to respond efficiently to Freedom of Information requests.
Arrangements are also in progress for the establishment of the Office of the Information Commissioner who will undertake a key role in relation to appeals under the legislation.
Given the extensive range of preparations now in train, I am fully confident that the deadlines for the introduction of the provisions of the Act, as set by the Oireachtas, will be adhered to.

Qst.Quest: if he will make additional finances available to Mallow General Hospital, County Cork, to facilitate the reopening of additional beds.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: The organisation of services at Mallow General Hospital is a matter for the Southern Health Board in the first instance. I have been advised by the board that the activity levels for Mallow General Hospital are in line with those agreed by the board in its service plan for 1997.

I have been further advised by the Southern Health Board that its current practice in relation to the delivery of hospital services is to increase day-patient work and out-patient throughput as an alternative to in-patient care. The board has in the past number of years supported this development through the designation of a number of dedicated day beds in Mallow General Hospital and the provision of equipment and staffing resources to enable an increase in day work. In the context of the board's assurances concerning the achievement of agreed activity levels at the hospital, I am satisfied that this is an appropriate approach to the delivery of services.

Qst.Quest: if he has received an application from an organisation (details supplied) in County Cork for national lottery funding for the construction of a day room at Mallow General Hospital; and if he will provide funding for this development.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: The application referred to by the Deputy has recently been received by my Department and is one of a number of applications for national lottery funding still under consideration. The organisation concerned will be informed directly when a decision has been made regarding the allocation of these funds.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Hospitals Funding.

Qst.Quest: if he will make adequate funding available to Mallow General Hospital to ensure that adult and child patients are accommodated in separate wards.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: The provision of health services at Mallow General Hospital and the determination of priorities for the development of the hospital are matters for the Southern Health Board in the first instance.

MainHeading.P: In this context my Department has in recent years provided significant additional capital funding for the development of out-patient, laboratory, physiotherapy and up-grading of the in-patient accommodation in the hospital in response to the board's priorities. The question of further developments at the hospital is firstly a matter for the Southern Health Board and my Department will continue to respond to the priorities identified by the board as sympathetically as possible.

Qst.hpid: Mr. N. Ahern Mr. N. Ahern
Qst.Quest: if he will give details of the reductions in funding made to the Cheshire Homes in the past two years which have forced them to levy charges of £100 per week on people availing of their respite beds; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: There has been no reduction in funding to Cheshire Homes in the last two years. Indeed, significant increases in revenue funding totalling £558,000 in 1996 and 1997 have been granted. Some homes have introduced a contribution of up to £100 per week for respite care. This applies to a small number of clients who are not medical card holders and whose means enable them to make a contribution.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Drug Trials.

Qst.Quest: if he will immediately provide a full and comprehensive report on the drug trials in the development of the three-in-one vaccines on Irish children in orphanages in view of the serious public disquiet; the number of those children with physical or mental handicap; the extent of adverse reaction to these trials; and if he will make a statement on the matter.
if children in orphanages were used in drug trials during the early 1960s and 1970s; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: I propose to take Questions Nos. 63 and 66 together.

As I explained last night to the House, recent media reports referring to the vaccination of children in orphanages in 1960-61 and in 1973 are not new. They were the subject of media comment in October 1990 and May 1991 and the then Minister, Deputy O'Hanlon, answered questions in the House on the matter on 7 May 1991. Essentially, we are now addressing the same issues.

The administration of the vaccines to the children in the children's homes was not in any way experimental. The children were due to be vaccinated in accordance with scheduled vaccination programmes at the time and the vaccines used were all approved under the regulatory framework which prevailed at the time.

MainHeading.P: The purpose of the studies was to determine which of the approved vaccines was most appropriate for use in the national vaccination programmes. The 1973 study was the larger study and was not confined to children's homes. The medical officers attending the homes gave their permission for the administration of the vaccines and were perceived to be acting in loco parentis in so doing. All the information available to me indicates that not only were the studies carried out in accordance with the then prevailing ethical guidelines but that additional measures were taken on a voluntary basis to ensure the highest standards of safety and efficacy.

The 1960-61 study was the subject of a subsequent report in the British Medical Journal of 21 April 1962. It described a comparative study comparing 3-in-1-diphtheria, tetanus, pertussis and separate polio immunisation with a 4-in-1, all vaccines combined, carried out on 52 children resident in five orphanages. The vaccines were administered to the children as part of the child immunisation programme.

The study was carried out in accordance with the then prevailing ethical guidelines and no adverse reactions occurred which were ascribed to the immunisations. The immunisations were conducted with the consent of the medical officers attending the children's homes and this is acknowledged in the BMJ article. It is a fact that information on this study has been in the public domain for 35 years.

In 1973, the Eastern Health Board noted above expected levels of transitory adverse reactions following the administration of DPT vaccine and discussed this with the pharmaceutical company. The health board co-operated with the company in carrying out a comparative study comparing four types of DPT vaccines, two of which were already in use and two of which were composed of the same basic components and which were approved.

Prior to the study being undertaken, Wellcome, the company supplying the vaccine, submitted a detailed Protocol to the NDAB, to which the board raised no objection. This was done on a voluntary basis as there was no statutory requirement to do so. The study proceeded on this basis. A total of 116 children were involved — 59 children being in the community and 57 children from two children's homes in the Dublin area. The children participating in this study were due to be immunised with DPT vaccine as part of the national immunisation programme. The results of the study were inconclusive, in that no significant difference between the vaccines emerged.

I am not aware of any other similar studies or trials involving children in orphanages but I have asked all health boards to report on the situation to the Department as a matter of urgency. When this information is received I will review the situation and decide what further action, if any, should be taken.

I have asked Glaxo Wellcome to provide a comprehensive report on the relevant studies. They have undertaken to provide such a report at the earliest possible date which I will make available to the Deputies.

Qst.Quest: the action, if any, he will take to assess the full extent of adverse reactions to the three-in-one vaccination in children; if he will publish the advice given by officials in his Department recommending the establishment of a board of assessors to decide compensation in such cases; if he will have a full inquiry into the possible links between the three-in-one vaccination and brain damage; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: Arrangements have been in place since 1968 under the Irish Medicines Board — formerly the National Drugs Advisory Board — to monitor adverse reactions to medicines, including vaccines. I have asked the board to provide me with an initial report on their assessment of reported reactions to DTP vaccine in the last five years and I will communicate the outcome of this assessment to the Deputy as soon as possible.

Officers of the Department, during the period 1979 to 1982, gave regular consideration to the establishment of an appropriate objective mechanism to determine compensation in proven cases of vaccine damage. However, having particular regard to the report of the expert group established in 1977 to assess individual cases and the May 1981 report of the DHSS on whooping cough vaccine no further consideration was given to this proposal after 1982.

The DHSS report had concluded that in general there was a very small risk associated with the pertussis vaccine, that it was not possible to clearly identify any specific syndrome associated with the vaccine and that there was no way of proving in any particular case that brain damage had been caused by the vaccine. As the reports of the Irish Expert Medical Group had been based on the balance of probabilities, it was felt that in the Irish context vaccine damage had not been absolutely proven. There is no record of any advice having been given by officials to the Minister in this matter.

Extensive international research has been conducted over many years regarding the possible link between pertussis vaccination and chronic brain damage. In the latest edition of Meylers Side Effect of Drugs, a publication of international standing, the conclusion is that there is insufficient evidence to indicate either the presence or absence of a casual relation between DTP vaccine and a range of conditions, including chronic neurological damage. In the circumstances, I do not propose to initiate further ongoing research on this matter but will continue to monitor closely all reported developments in this area. At a practical level I would like to reiterate the advice given in the recently published guidelines on immunisation in which particular stress is laid on the identification of children who may have contraindications to this particular vaccine.

Qst.Quest: if he will concede the 9 per cent increase in subscription costs being sought by the VHI; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: On 26 June 1997 the chairman of the Voluntary Health Insurance Board wrote to the previous Minister informing him of the board's decision to implement a price increase of 9 per cent approximately on all VHI schemes, with effect from 1 September 1997.

Under the Voluntary Health Insurance (Amendment) Act, 1996, the board must give not less than 30 days prior notice to the Minister where it proposes to increase premium charges. The Act provides that the board may give effect to any increase unless the Minister, within 30 days of the notification, directs the board in writing not to do so.
The board has provided my Department with information relating to its decision to increase its premium charges. I expect consideration of this matter to be completed very shortly.

Qst.Quest: the progress, if any, achieved by the Naas hospital design team; if he expects the plans to advance sufficiently to facilitate commencement of site works in 1997; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Health (Mr. Cowen) Brian Cowen
Speaker.P: As the Deputy is aware, the revised development brief for Naas General Hospital was formally approved on 4 June 1997. This approval allows the Eastern Health Board to proceed with the preparation of a revised development control plan for the hospital development and the drafting of a more detailed phase II development option within the approved cost limits. The design and project teams are currently involved in discussions with regard to the various options for phase II of the hospital development.

I have been assured that the planning process for the hospital development is being progressed as quickly as is possible and that the target date for the commencement of site works is January-February 1998.

Qst.Quest: the plans, if any, he has in respect of the public housing programme; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Molloy) Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister of State at the Department of the Environment (Mr. Molloy)
Speaker.P: The Action Programme for the Millennium reiterates the Government's commitment to a continuation of the local authority house construction programme. The level of next year's programme will be determined by the Government in the context of decisions on the 1998 Estimates of expenditure.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Social Welfare Benefits.

Qst.Quest: the proposals, if any, he has to review the threshold for married spouses in relation to the retention of the adult dependants allowance for partners or spouses; if he will review the matter in the context of the current threshold of £60 in view of the fact that lone parents in similar circumstances are allowed earn £112; and the proposals, if any, he has to give equality to women in similar circumstances.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: Different categories of social welfare recipients have differing needs. The social welfare system must be flexible enough to respond adequately to these needs. The different methods of assessing earnings as between the various social welfare payment schemes and as between different household situations reflects specific policies which are aimed at targeting particular groups of recipients for special attention.

It should be noted that the two household situations described in the question are not similar. One relates to a household where there is a single earner only, while the other relates to a household where the income is provided by two people.

In relation to the one-parent family payment, which was introduced earlier this year, research carried out by the ESRI has clearly shown that one-parent families are particularly at risk of poverty and social exclusion. Under this scheme, a lone parent can earn up to £6,000 a year without affecting his-her entitlement to payment. This measure is aimed at facilitating lone parents who wish to return to the workforce, by providing positive support so that, over time, they can gain a foothold in the labour market and become less reliant on social welfare for their income needs.

The £60 earnings threshold is one of a number of different methods which are used to determine whether a claimant's spouse is to be regarded a financial dependant for qualified adult allowance purposes. Where the spouse of a claimant is adjudged to be financially dependent, then the allowance, together with full child dependant allowances are paid to the claimant, in addition to his or her personal rate of payment. Where the spouse is not regarded as a dependant, then the allowance is not payable and only half of the child dependant allowances are payable.

However, the sudden withdrawal of the qualified adult allowance and half of the child dependant allowances where the income of the spouse of a claimant exceeds £60 a week creates a sharp poverty trap. The national agreement: “Partnership 2000” provides that “measures to alleviate this poverty trap will be considered, in consultation with the social partners”.

MainHeading.P: As a first step in addressing this problem regulations which will be made later this year, will provide for the introduction of a tapered withdrawal of the qualified adult allowance in the case of recipients of unemployment benefit, unemployment assistance, disability benefit, disability allowance and pre-retirement allowance, with effect from October. Under the new arrangements, where the spouse's weekly income exceeds £60 the allowance will be withdrawn on the basis of £6 for each additional £5 of income, with the allowance being withdrawn completely where the spouse's weekly income exceeds £90. It is estimated that approximately 9,760 families will benefit under this proposal at an annual cost of almost £10 million with an average gains for families amounting to over £19 a week.

In order to ensure fairness in the way that the State supports families, whether the parents concerned are married, cohabiting or parenting alone, a working group has been appointed to identify ways of ensuring consistent and equitable treatment of such households under the social welfare and income tax codes. As part of its remit, the working group has been charged with the task of reviewing the concept of adult dependency, as well as examining the income support arrangements for labour market programmes. The establishment of this group also marks the first stage in meeting the commitment contained in the National Anti-Poverty Strategy to examine individualisation of payments. The group is due to report by March 1998.

Qst.Quest: if a family income supplement is payable in the case of a person (details supplied) in County Kildare for the period June 1995 to January 1996 in view of the particular circumstances; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. D. Ahern) Dermot Ahern
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Social Welfare (Mr. D. Ahern)
Speaker.P: The person concerned qualified for family income supplement in April 1994 and was paid until April 1995 at a rate of £33 per week. She again applied in September 1995 but the family income, including the income of her husband who had taken up employment in the meantime, exceeded the appropriate limit for entitlement to the supplement and the application was disallowed. The decision to disallow the application was upheld on appeal and there is no claim for payment of the supplement for the period in question.

Qst.askee: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform
Qst.Quest: the position regarding the acquisition of a site for a new Garda station at Leixlip, County Kildare; if his attention has been drawn to the total number of sites currently under consideration; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. O'Donoghue) John O'Donoghue
Speaker.NameTxt: Minister for Justice, Equality and Law Reform (Mr. O'Donoghue)
Speaker.P: The present position is that the Office of Public Works has been requested to look for a greenfield site or a suitable building to buy or lease in the area, for use as a new Garda station for Leixlip. As yet, I am still awaiting a reply from that office.

Qst.Quest: the current position regarding the proposed extension to Clonaslee vocational school, Clonaslee; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: Officials of the post-primary building unit of my Department have examined the stage I documentation — site suitability and report — which was submitted by the school's design team as part of the architectural planning process for the facilities at Clonaslee vocational school.

As this submission was found to be in order, a planning and briefing meeting was held on 17 June 1997. As a result of this meeting, a revised schedule of accommodation was agreed and the project has now reached stage II of the Department's design team procedures.
It is not possible to say at this stage when building will commence.

MainHeading.Title: Written Answers - Teacher Appointments.

Qst.Quest: when he intends to appoint a second teacher to all the one-teacher schools in County Mayo in view of promises in this regard.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: In March 1997 the outgoing Minister for Education agreed staffing arrangements for primary schools for the next school year with the Irish National Teachers Organisation. These agreed arrangements were based on the allocation of all surplus posts available for redistribution from the demographic dividend for the 1997-98 school year.

The Deputy will be aware that the Action Programme for the Millennium contains a commitment to give primary education a clear priority in allocating resources. In this context, the programme specifically states that one teacher schools with ten or more pupils will receive a second teacher.
Currently, there are 103 one teacher primary schools with ten or more pupils in the country. A further 23 schools are due to become one teacher schools from 1 September 1997.

MainHeading.P: Since there are no teaching posts available to me from the 1997-98 demographic dividend for allocation to these schools, I am currently examining a range of options with a view to identifying the most appropriate way to fulfil the Government's commitments to one teacher schools, and especially to the 23 schools referred to above.

Qst.Quest: if he will urgently consider the appointment of a special resource teacher for a school (details supplied) in County Wexford in view of the problems the school is experiencing with its second class and the fact that they are losing their seventh assistant teacher; if they will retain their existing teacher as a special resource teacher; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: In March 1997 the outgoing Minister for Education agreed staffing arrangements for primary schools for the next school year with the Irish National Teachers Organisation.

These agreed arrangements were based on the allocation of all surplus posts available for redistribution from the demographic dividend for the 1997-98 school year and included the allocation of 26 resource teacher posts to primary schools with effect from September 1997.

Accordingly, I am not in a position at present to allocate additional resource teacher posts to primary schools. However, I assure the Deputy that the needs of all schools, including the school to which he refers, will be considered in the context of any future allocation of resource teacher posts which may be undertaken.

Qst.Quest: if he will sanction a concessionary post in accordance with disadvantaged status in relation to the amalgamation of two schools (details supplied) in Dublin 11 in order that the two remedial teachers will be retained.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: I am pleased to inform the Deputy that, in accordance with normal arrangements relating to the amalgamation of schools, the two remedial teacher posts to which the Deputy refers will be retained as part of the amalgamation arrangement.

In March 1997 the outgoing Minister for Education agreed staffing arrangements for primary schools for the next school year with the Irish National Teachers Organisation. These agreed arrangements were based on the allocation of all surplus posts available for redistribution from the demographic dividend for the 1997-98 school year. Accordingly, I am not in a position at present to allocate additional concessionary teaching posts to primary schools.
In the event of additional concessionary teaching posts becoming available, the needs of the school in question will be considered.

Qst.Quest: if he will give urgent consideration to the inclusion of the Ballymun comprehensive schools in the disadvantaged scheme in view of the fact that they meet all the criteria and all other schools in the area are so designated; and if he will make a statement regarding permanent staff appointments to these schools.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: The case of the school referred to by the Deputy will be considered when next it is possible to allocate additional posts under the disadvantaged scheme. As the school is in a supernumerary staffing situation, it is not possible to sanction any permanent appointments for the 1997-98 school year.

Qst.Quest: if he will examine the need for an regional technical college in north Kildare; if he will carry out an assessment to quantify the need for such a college in view of the ever increasing industrial requirements in the area; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: The steering Committee on the Future Development of Higher Education was asked to examine “within the overall national context. the needs for higher education on a regional basis.”. Following its examination of Dublin and the surrounding counties, the committee recommended Blanchardstown, Dublin 15 as the appropriate location for the establishment of a new regional technical college to serve the north, north-west and north-east Dublin regions as well as growth areas in County Meath and County Kildare.

In the light of the steering committee report, which was accepted as a benchmark for future planning in the sector, a decision was taken to establish an regional technical college at Blanchardstown. My Department is in negotiation with Fingal County Council regarding the acquisition of approximately 45 acres of land as a site for the college.

A planning group is currently undertaking the development of a strategic plan for the college which includes, inter alia, industry links, support services and research and consultancy. The courses at certificate, diploma and degree levels will focus on the needs and the human resource requirements of leading-edge high technology industries and on languages, business, science and engineering fields.
The new regional technical college will initially cater for around 1,000 students.

Qst.Quest: if his attention has been drawn to the need for an extension at Confey College, Leixlip, County Kildare; the immediate proposals, if any, he has to meet this need; if he will ensure that the necessary financial provision is made in 1997 or in 1998; when the extension will be operational; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: An extension is currently being planned for Confey Community College, Leixlip, County Kildare, to cater for a long-term enrolment of 750 pupils.

Because the project is in the early stages of architectural planning, the question of funding in 1997 does not arise. Decisions on the 1998 capital programme will be taken in the light of the extent of funding made available and the Department's other commitments and priorities in the capital area.
It is not possible at this point to give a definite date for construction to begin.

Qst.Quest: when a sports hall will be provided at Scoil Mhuire, Clane, County Kildare; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: Architectural planning for an extension to Scoil Mhuire, Clane, County Kildare has commenced and is at stage I of the Department's design team procedures. A physical education hall is included as part of the schedule of accommodation for the extension. At this early stage of planning, it is not possible to say when construction will commence.

Qst.Quest: when a design team was appointed in respect of the proposed extension to Scoil Mhuire, Clane, County Kildare; the work already completed on the various developmental preparations involved; if he will ensure that each stage is expedited to facilitate the earliest possible commencement date for the project; and if he will make a statement on the matter.

Speaker.hpid: Minister for Education (Mr. Martin) Micheál Martin
Speaker.P: Interviews for the appointment of a design team in respect of the building project at Scoil Mhuire, Clane, County Kildare, took place on 13 January 1997 and the commission was awarded shortly thereafter.

Architectural planning for the proposed extension is at Stage I of the Department's design team procedures. The further stages in the architectural planning process are: outline sketch scheme, developed sketch scheme, detailed design and bill of quantities. When the detailed design and bill of quantities have been prepared the project will be ready to proceed to tender. Every effort will be made to ensure that there are no delays at any of the stages in the planning process.
